title: new-musselburgh-bar-gets-go-ahead
story: The Musselburgh Bar and Kitchen, formerly the Mexican restaurant Habaneros on High Street, was granted a iation of premises licence by East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board last week.Owner Star Pubs  Bars had applied for: extension of opening hours from midnight to am on a Thursday use of premises for clubs and group meetings an outdoor drinking area changes both internally to the building to re-position bar and seating areas and extension of the rear drinking smoking area outside.A number of objections centred around concerns of possible noise disturbance and smoke from the outdoor area.The board heard that the outdoor smoking area would be moved from its present location away from neighbouring properties and that this area would also be covered by CCTV.Members of the licensing board agreed to grant permission with conditions. They included that children and young people under  could only be on the premises after pmthey were having a meal or attending a private, pre-arranged , and that CCTV was operational both within and outside the building.In addition, the beer garden would close at pm and an entertainment licence was not granted so no recorded or live music could be played outside.The new bar had previously received planning permission.A spokesperson for Star Pubs  Bars said the premises would be turned into ldquoa modern premium bar.She said it was hoped that a new licensee would take on the venture, which would offer food throughout the day and alfresco dining.She said the proposed investment followed another recent refurbishment project involving Star Pubs  Bars at The Seaglass Inn, Port Seton, previously the Wemyss Hotel.

title: general-election-candidates-lock-horns-hustings
story: The event ndash at St Andrew Blackadder Church ndash saw the candidates answering questions submitted by the public ahead of the election next Thursday.Organised by North Berwick and District Association of Churches, it was chaired by Keith Stewart QC.Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield began by saying that serving as MP for the last two years had been a pleasure and a privilege.He also said: ldquoI am the only pro-Union person sitting on this  that can win here, which Conservative candidate Craig Hoy was quick to disagree with.David Sisson, UKIP, used a cookie jar analogy to make his partyrsquos position on Brexit clear saying: ldquoThe cookies belong to us. Itrsquos time we get them back and we can work out how we split them up once we have them back.Answering a question on how to tackle climate change Robert OrsquoRiordan, Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoI think that one of the best ways is to stay within the EU.The SNPrsquos candidate Kenny MacAskill said the country needed to disinvest in fossil fuels.The next question asked candidatesthey thought there ought to be a  per cent majority threshold on referendums.Mr MacAskill said he didnrsquot, adding: ldquoPeople werenrsquot voting for a no deal Brexit, that was never put forward. I agree that the majority prevails, but I think we have to realise thatyou win by one the winner canrsquot have all.Mr Hoy said he would agree there should be a threshold in future elections.He added: ldquoI understand why Kenny doesnrsquot support it because the SNP can barely secure  per cent, never mind  per cent, for independence.Candidates were then asked why they should be trusted by the public.Mr Sisson took this opportunity to point out that he wasnrsquot a politician and he was standing because he felt it was the right thing to do.Mr Whitfield suggested constituents believe those who did what they said they would do, adding: ldquoI think the Government breaking the law and having to be told by the Supreme Court that they have broken the law severely undermines the trust in politicians.Next, with Russia raised as a potential threat, candidates were asked about defence spending.MacAskill thought the defence budget should not change, saying: ldquoThe dficulty that faces our military is that everything is being put into nuclear weapons and Trident. I do not believe in Trident, I do not believe in nuclear weapons.Mr Sisson questioned the British Armyrsquos future as ldquoBritish defence more and more seems to be integrated into European forces.Mr Hoy said the Conservatives would increase expenditure on defence by . per cent above the rate of inflation. He added: ldquoTrident makes us safer.Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThere is a commitment from a Labour government to maintain its position in NATO and the two per cent. There is a commitment to renew Trident.Mr OrsquoRiordan also said he would maintain the two per cent GDP target, adding: ldquoIrsquom not sure of the nature of the Russian threat ndash I think it is much more to do with cyberspace and the threat to our democracy.ldquoAs we know, Boris Johnson has a dossier on his desk which he hasnrsquot released that talks about Russian intervention in the European referendum and in the European elections.Question then focused on healing the isions from Brexit, Islamophobia, and anti-Semitism in politics.Mr Hoy said he thought ldquothe issue of accountability in politics is extremely important, adding that, on comments made by Boris Johnson mocking Muslim womenrsquos appearance, he thought ldquothe Prime Minister should be held to the same account for any particular phrases that he uses but ldquothat would be for him to comment on.Mr Whitfield said he believed the Labour Party should apologise to the Jewish community for its handling of complaints of anti-Semitism in the party.He added: ldquoWith regard to what happens to bring society together widely, I think a referendum or confirmatory vote would allow people to discuss and debate and then to express their feelings through ballot box.Mr MacAskill called for better education and more enforcement, adding: ldquoYou cannot just whip up hatred and say what you like.Lastly, the candidates were asked what three things they had done for East Lothian.Mr Hoy mentioned implementing the Change and Check breast cancer campaign, voting for East Lothian Councilrsquos emergency climate change declaration, and working with police to tackle anti-social behaviour and drug use in the county.Mr Whitfield highlighted helping people with Universal Credit payments, taking county art therapy charity The Teapot Trust to Westminster and, in his previous job as a primary school teacher, teaching children in East Lothian who he had now seen getting jobs and apprenticeships.Mr OrsquoRiordan listed his involvement in setting up the hustings and working with church groups, working towards achieving the Drem-Gullane path, and convening East Lothian Liberal Democrats.Mr MacAskill cited, in his time as Justice Secretary, establishing the CashBack for Communities scheme, helping implement minimum alcohol pricing, and reducing youth offending.Mr Sisson answered by describing his work as an electrician for the council, choosing to stand as an MP, and his involvement with Musselburgh Amateur Musical Association.When asked to sing the last line of his answer by the chair, the UKIP candidate obliged, belting out to the filled church that he hoped to deliver democratic freedom to constituents.

title: bid-build-new-hotel-replace-gullanes-mallard
story: Gullanersquos The Mallard Hotel has been run by the same family for more than half a century but new plans reveal a dramatic change for the East Links Road venue.Information boards were on display in the hotel last Thursday afternoon before a presentation was given to the villagersquos community council.Currently, the hotel is made up of  bedrooms, with a bar, bistro and garden room open to the public.However, the proposed new hotel ndash which would be built over three floors ndash would include  bedrooms, as well as a restaurant, lounge and spa facilities.Structured House Group is behind the plans, with a formal planning application expected to be with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department before the end of the year.Hotel owners Cameron and Susan Law intend to step down from the business, which has been in the family for  years,the proposals are given the green light.Susan, who is also chairman of Muirfield Riding Therapy, which offers free horse-riding for people with disabilities, stressed that The Mallard Hotel remained open for business as usual and would continue to be so for the foreseeable future.She told the Courier: ldquoI think, initially, I was quite shocked that it was going to be knocked down but in retrospect it is the best thing really.ldquoObviously, we will be sad to see it go but we will take The Mallard Hotel with us is how I am thinking now. It is very dear to us.About  people attended the public exhibition in the hotel and Tony Thomas, representing the developers, was pleased with how the six-hour drop-in event had gone.He said: ldquoIt was overwhelmingly positive ndash mainly because it is not housing [being proposed].ldquoThe vast majority of people really, really like the design. The only slight hiccup was two or three immediate neighbours were concerned over parking so we will look at that. If there is not enough parking, it spills out onto the street.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, was at the presentation and the meeting afterwards.He said there were concerns about the proposals and noted residentsrsquo worries about parking and traffic generated by the new hotel.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThe plans were well presented.ldquoWhat they are proposing is a fine installation and it looks as though it would be a good, upmarket, modern hotel with good facilities.ldquoThere is considerable concern in the community about the problems likely to arise from car parking.ldquoThat was the big issue in the discussions at the community council meeting.ldquoThere were a lot of people indicating signicant concern on that point. It is quite a heavily built-up residential area and already the parking is under pressure from residents.ldquoI would say the new hotel has signicantly more rooms than the present one. It is also supposedly going to have an upmarket restaurant, which will attract evening customers.

title: busy-a198-near-tranent-closed-several-evenings
story: There will be a full overnight closure of the A between the two roundabouts at the Bankton Junction. Drivers wanting to cross the bridge which travels over the A, linking Tranent to Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton, will face a y ersion.Joining and exiting the A at the junction will still be possible.From Monday until next Saturday , ldquoessential expansion joint replacement works will be carried out between the hours of pm and am each night.Closure of the bridge footpaths will also be required while the work is under way.Pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcycles under cc looking to cross the bridge will be marshalled safely across by the on-site team.A southbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A in an easterly direction towards Gladsmuir Junction.Traffic will be directed to take the exit at Gladsmuir Junction and, at the roundabout, will take the third exit onto the B.At the following roundabout, traffic will take the third exit to join the A but in a westerly direction towards Bankton Junction.From there, traffic will exit at Bankton Junction and take the second exit at the roundabout to rejoin the A.Meanwhile, A northbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A westbound.Traffic will proceed towards Dolphingstone and will exit at the next junction.From there, traffic will then take a right turn onto the A, crossing the A and will take a further right turn to rejoin the eastbound carriageway of the A.Traffic will follow this route to take the exit at Bankton Junction and at the roundabout will take the first exit to rejoin the A.All works are weather dependent and may be cancelled or rescheduledweather conditions are not favourable.This scheme has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, the emergency services and East Lothian Council.

title: rugby-players-tackle-giant-jenners-xmas-tree
story: This yearrsquos tree is a ft-high Norway spruce that was grown in Stirling. It was supplied by Conox, which has provided Christmas trees for Edinburghrsquos Christmas market and Leicester Square in London.Ross High RFC has helped get the tree in place in Jenners for the past  years, a tradition which started after one former member had a connection to the company K which helps hoist the tree and put on the lights.John Tinlin, Ross High Rugby Club president, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos tree was not as big as it usually is but the guys all know the script.ldquoWe have to take the tree in through the revolving doors at the front of the store since there is no other way to bring it in, so we need to be very careful.ldquoThe doors are actually taken off so there is enough room. It was a tight squeeze but we managed.ldquoIt was well wrapped, which made it a lot easier.Ross High sent a team of  along to help bring the tree into the iconic Princes Street store, with the whole process taking just  minutes.John added: ldquoIt was quicker than usual.The team volunteer their time but are rewarded with pizza by the staff at Jenners.The process is a very Scottish affair, with rugby club members wearing kilts and music performed on bagpipes.Once the tree is brought in, staff from K abseil from the roof, helping to hoist it up and put the lights on ndash a process which takes place overnight.The lights were turned on by five-year-old Chloe from Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital, who won the opportunity through a charity auction.Following reports that Jenners might leave Princes Street and moving to another city centre location, John added: ldquoHopefully the tradition goes ahead again next year as we have been a part of it for such a long time.

title: grandfathers-five-decade-link-christian-aid-recognised
story: John Woodrsquos links to Christian Aid date back more than half a century and he has now been presented with a certicate to mark his commitment to the good cause.The -year-old, of Haddingtonrsquos Herdmanflatt, was taken by surprise at a recent quiz night in St Maryrsquos Parish Church for the charity, which works to support sustainable development, stop poverty and provide disaster relief.He said: ldquoI suppose after receiving the certicate I felt quite humbled about it really.ldquoIt was a surprise and I was pleased afterwards.The certicate reads: ldquoChristian Aid presents this award to John Wood in recognition of his  plus years of outstanding commitment in transforming the lives of the poor, marginalised and vulnerable.Mr Wood first got involved with the charity in the early s when he was instrumental in setting up the Haddington branch of the organisation.It has grown considerably since then, raising thousands of pounds for the international charity each year.The grandfather-of-four said: ldquoA chap from Edinburgh came out, Jimmy Hodge, who was the sole organiser of Christian Aid in Scotland at that time, and spoke about Christian Aid in the West Church.ldquoThat was the start of Christian Aid in Haddington.ldquoThe first big event was a sponsored -mile walk.ldquoAll the churches in Haddington were involved and walked to North Berwick, along the coast and back to Haddington.Since then, ious events have been organised for the charity, with the annual focus on Christian Aid Week.Members from Holy Trinity Church, St Maryrsquos Parish Church and West Church join forces for the house-to-house collection, which takes place each May.Mr Wood, who stepped down from the townrsquos Christian Aid committee earlier this year, remains involved with Holy Trinity Church, where he has been a minister for a number of years.Graham Coe, who is a member of the townrsquos Christian Aid committee, handed over the certicate to Mr Wood, who also worked with the Courier for almost  years firstly, as a compositor and then as a proof reader.Janet Chrystal, Christian Aid organiser for Haddington, said: ldquoJohn has been a mainstay in Haddington for a number of years.ldquoThe churches in Haddington have worked together for Christian Aid and we have had a joint committee and John represented Holy Trinity Church.ldquoHe stepped back at the end of August and his place has been taken by two people, which tells you his level of commitment.ldquoHe did not know he was getting the presentation, it was a surprise, but, of course, he was there as he always supports Christian Aid events.

title: santas-helping-send-north-berwick-teenager-ghana
story: Beth Poole, , who lives on Wamphray Road, left North Berwick High School in the summer.Before attending the University of Glasgow to study neuroscience, she is taking a year out to teach English and maths at a junior school in the Volta region of the West African country.She leaves next month and will be in Africa for eight months, living with a host family based within the community while she is out there.And to help fund her trip, she is organising this yearrsquos North Berwick Santa Run, which takes place next Sunday .Her African adventure is organised through Project Trust.Beth told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom really excited and nervous ndash it will be nerve-wracking at first. I am hoping it will be very rewarding. Irsquom excited to see all of the new cultures as well ndash Irsquom hoping to take some sports gear with me, Irsquove been asking some friends for their old hockey sticks.ldquoIrsquom going to teach my own class when Irsquom out there so Irsquom going on a one-week teaching course before I go.In order to go to Ghana, Beth needs to raise pound, and currently has pound, left, so has decided to host this yearrsquos Santa Run.Registration opens at .am on the day, with runs beginning at am outside the Hope Rooms ndash k, k and k runs are on offer.The route takes runners across ious parts of North Berwick, with the k heading out to Broad Sands.The routes involve water and climbing over rocky sections, so appropriate shoes and winter clothing are advised.There are some age restrictions on the runs: the k is open for all ages, with children under seven to be accompanied by an adult the k is open to those  years and over and the k for those aged  and over.Entry for under-sevens is pound, under-s pay pound and adults pound, with Scottish Athletics members receiving a pound discount.All of the money raised at the Santa Run goes towards Bethrsquos fundraising efforts.She added: ldquoItrsquos been a lot more dficult to organise than I thought but hopefully Irsquove done enough. I know itrsquos quite tough to run on the beach, but we will all be fine.Enter the run at entrycentral festival  or email bethpoole@gmailSince the run is Santa Christmas themed, participants are encouraged to wear Christmas clothing.Dogs are welcomewell behaved and on a lead.Those not taking part are welcome to spectate and support, with tea, coffee and cakes for sale in the Hope Rooms.Beach Wheelchairs, where Bethrsquos mum Cath is a volunteer, is also open and available for hire to allow everyone to take part in the event.Participants receive a Santa hat on arrival and a hot drink and home baking after completing their run.

title: tims-tales-anne-franks-legacy
story: WHILE watching a film adaptation of John Greenrsquos wonderful book The Fault In Our Stars last night, there was a scene in which the main character, a young woman suffering from cancer, climbs the stairs into the attic used by Anne Frank.My six-year-old Skye was watching with me and she was having her last five minutes before bedtime. But she asked why the young woman was so determined to climb the stairs, even though she was clearly very ill and finding it dficult.This led to me mentioning who Anne Frank was and that people visit the attic because itrsquos the place where she hid.ldquoWhy was she hiding  was the inevitable question, just as bedtime arrived.I was suddenly presented with a dilemma, not so much that bedtime was now delayed, but how to explain to a six-year-old the depth of evil and hatred that was the reason for Anne Frank having to hide in an attic with her family. And then whether to explain what happened to her after she was discovered.I knew that I couldnrsquot just ignore her question. So we searched for images of Anne Frank, which meant she became a real person for my daughter.Skye studied her and said she looked nice and kind, and asked again why she was hiding.I explained that people who didnrsquot even know her hated her just because she was a bit dferent to them. I couldnrsquot explain the horrors of genocide and concentration camps, but she understood that Anne Frank and her family must have been really scared to hide in an attic.ldquoWhat happened to her  asked Skye as she dressed for bed.This was not a bedtime story I wanted to tell. Indeed, for a child so young, it was not a story I wanted to tell at all. She knows there are bad people and staying safe is important, but we feel the need to protect our children from the evil and hatred that is sadly so deep-seated.But it is at this young age that the seeds of intolerance and hatred can be plantedthey are not encouraged and helped to feel empathy to others, including those who are dferent in fact, especially those who are dferent.So I told her a lsquochild-friendlyrsquo version of Anne Frankrsquos story,there can be such a thing. I gave no details of the horror of the Holocaust but we imagined how she must have missed her family when they were split up, and how sad it was that she died not long before the war ended.She wanted to look at Anne Frankrsquos photo again and say goodnight to her.ldquoThank goodness that could never happen to us here, could it dad ldquoNo, that is not going to happen, and we have to make sure it doesnrsquot happen to anyone  either, I reassured her.I felt quite emotional as I went downstairs with my kids sleeping safely in their cosy beds. I thought of the families in Syria who cannot keep their children safe from hatred and violence. I knew that such horrors could happen anywhere, at any time yes, even here yes, maybe even to us or our neighbours or friends. In fact, hatred of dference is indeed amongst us.A friend of mine was on a bus heading from East Lothian into Edinburgh last week and witnessed a horrible racist verbal assault on a Polish family. The horric murders in London are also part of the same hatred of dference ndash a man so full of hatred for people who think dferently that he randomly killed two amazing young people.Hatred is a virus that can infect any society and any inidual in it. History has taught us that fanning its flames can be an easy way for politicians to win power. But like real fire, once itrsquos released it can spread and destroy uncontrollably.People say fight fire with fire, but here the comparison ends, for we cannot fight hatred with hatred. Hatred only spawns more of it.And so I searched for words of that remarkable young woman Anne Frank, who left her diary behind, unknowing that it would be her gt to the world. Words I could share with my daughter, from one young thinking child to another. Despite writing at a time of unimaginable fear and horror, in her diary she has left us a timeless message of hope that comes from her rejection of hate:ldquoItrsquos dficult in times like these ideals, dreams and cherished hopes rise within us, only to be crushed by grim reality. Itrsquos a wonder I havenrsquot abandoned all my ideals, they seem so absurd and impractical. Yet I cling to them because I still believe, in spite of everything, that people are truly good at heart.It is our responsibility to live up to that inspiring message from a young woman who was a victim of the hate she rejected utterly to show our children, our family and friends, our colleagues and those we meet on a bus, that love, tolerance, empathy and respect of dference is the counter to hate.And we should expect no less from all our politicians.

title: bid-replace-old-boxing-gym-housing

title: general-election-2019-voting-system-works
story: Unlike the single transferable vote system used in the East Lothian Council elections, FPTP is a straight race to the line, with voters only allowed to vote for one candidate and the candidate with the most votes winning.Voters mark an x on their ballot paper next to the candidate they wish to vote for - they must not mark any of the other candidates boxes or their ballot paper will be spoilt.Once all the votes across the constituency have been tallied, the candidate with the most votes is elected.Voting takes place between am and pm on Thursday, December , with the East Lothian result expected to be declared some time early in the morning, potentially any time between about am and about am, although this is liable to change depending on how close the result is.The final UK-wide result is not expected to be known until well into the Friday morning.The General Election is to elect the UK Government at Westminster, with all  seats across Scotland, England, Wales and Northern Ireland up for grabs.To win a majority, a party would need at least  seats.Traditionally, a General Election is held only once every five years, but this will be the third General Election since May , coming only two and a half years after the last one in June .The last election resulted in a hung parliament, with the Conservatives losing their majority and finishing with  seats, while Labour came second with seats.In Scotland, the SNP won  of the  seats, more than half, although that did represent a loss of  seats from their historic  result. However, it was still enough to see them finish as the third largest party across the UK, well ahead of the fourth-placed Liberal Democrats, who won  seats UK-wide.The Conservatives increased their number of seats in Scotland from one to  to finish second, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats, both of whom also had won only one seat in Scotland in , also made gains, winning seven and four seats respectively.East Lothian, which had been one of a swathe of Labour seats to fall to the SNP in , was one of Labours gains last time around in , Martin Whitfield overturning sitting MP George Kerevans majority of nearly , to regain the seat for Labour with a majority of ,.The Conservatives Sheila Low was a close third, a little over  votes behind the SNP.Unlike in the council elections and the Scottish Parliament elections,  and -year-olds cannot vote in the General Election - voters must be  or over.

title: general-election-2019-statement-east-lothian-constituency-conservative-candidate-craig-hoy
story: East Lothian is the second fastest growing area in Scotland. The speed of development is challenging our schools, our hospitals and GPs surgeries, our roads and our railways. And itrsquos challenging our local environment: the very thing that attracts so many people to live here.So,elected as your MP, I will put East Lothianrsquos infrastructure first ndash and stand firm against any attempt by the SNP to force thousands more homes on East Lothian. This will be my number one priority.Climate change affects us all but it will hit younger residents hardest. As a member of East Lothian Council, I backed the climate change emergency declaration. But itrsquos vital we match words with deeds. As your MP, I will do that. I am committed to promoting a secure and low-carbon-based economy, supporting sustainable local transport and resources across East Lothian.I also want to tackle the scourge of poverty in East Lothian. The best way of lting people out of poverty is to create new, skilled jobs and apprenticeships. Thatrsquos why I will push for more investment to create jobs at the former Cockenzie Power Station site and the new Innovation Park at Queen Margaret University.As your MP, I will work hard for those who work hard. But I will work twice as hard for the poorest and most vulnerable members of our community. I will always stand up for older people and will push for the BBC to reverse its decision to remove free TV licences from the over-s.But we cannot escape one simple fact. The SNP donrsquot see this election as being about East Lothianrsquos future but instead as an opportunity to mount lsquoone final heaversquo for independence. And Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour Party is ready to help them do it.The SNP wants next year to be the year of two isive referendums. We need to send a clear message to Nicola Sturgeon: we donrsquot want another independence referendum.The only way to do that is to vote Scottish Conservative, because Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour Party is simply too weak and ided to win here.My position is unambiguous: no s, no buts, no IndyRef.Put simply, I want to go to Westminster to be East Lothianrsquos voice in Parliament, not remove your voice from it.

title: Rosemary Goring  More female leaders offers hope of safer  stronger world
story: Within a decade of that declaration,   set the wheels spinning on what promises to become a century or more of exceptional chaos and carnage in the middle east, and far beyond.Everyone can get it wrong, especially those whose closely argued ideas are reduced to soundbites. And so it might yet prove with another of Fukuyamas pronouncements. It is his contention that the developed world has recently become more peaceable thanks to women as heads of state and in positions of political influence.Ive often heard people say there would be less conflict and fewer warswomen were in charge. Usually its the middle-aged and elderly ndash mothers, aunts and grandmothers ndash who make this claim. They have never scaled the heights of a male-dominated industry or profession, yet hope that the women they see in charge are imbued with the same gentle, conciliatory and nurturing personalities as themselves. And there, I would suggest, is the snag.Nor am I being unduly cynical. A study by the University of Chicago covering  years of European historyhas shown that not only were queens more inclined to take their country into battle than kings, but also more certain to win.:Nicola Sturgeon announces funding for women leaders schemeIn Victorias day, Britain was at war with some part of the empire, or would-be empire, almost every year of her reign. Three hundred years earlier, Elizabeth I set a gold standard for empire building, showing her mettle as she fought off Spanish incursions, despatching her own conquistadors across the globe, and managing to maintain stability in a precariously inflammable period of religious stre asshe were refereeing a game of croquet.The leader of the Chicago study, Professor Oeindrila Dube, points out that you need only think of Catherine the Great of Russia, or Isabella I of Castile to appreciate that, in previous centuries, royal women were every bit as war-like as men. When circumstances dictated, they didnrsquot hesitate to shed blood.Quite how they felt privately, of course, is another matter. Henry VIIIs daughter, who earned the title Bloody Mary after condemning almost  Protestants and religious dissenters to the pyre, was apparently a warm and affectionate person. What her notorious actions indicate, perhaps, is less a vengeful nature and more the vicious tenor of her times.Even our own Mary Queen of Scots was no peacenik, riding at the head of her troops on more than one occasion and, far from avoiding conflict, at times seeming actively to court it.Professor Dubersquos analysis of royal authority shows that when a queen was in power, she was even more effective than a man. Since she would often work in partnership with her consort, her subjects were effectively getting two warriors for the price of one. There is, however, a great dference between what was required of female rulers in the reign of Victoria and before, and attitudes in modern times.In almost every era prior to our own Elizabethan age, to be a woman was seen to be weak. Debate raged across Europe in the th century about how worthy and capable females could ever beplaced on a throne. John Knox, enraged at Mary of Guise becoming Regent of Scotland, spoke for many when he declared her appointment ldquoas seemly a sight as to put a saddle upon the back of an unruly cow.Given such hostility, itrsquos entirely possible that it was not the assistance of their husbands that made Boudiccas of high-ranking women, but the need to show that they were every bit as aggressive and dangerous as men. The message needed to be sent that anyone who tried to topple them would live ndash albeit briefly ndash to regret it.Margaret Thatcher thrust us into battle in the Falklands where many other prime ministers might have hesitated. You could see her pugnacity, on this and other inflammatory issues, as the problem with Fukuyamas theory. Women who reach the political pinnacle today have had to fight to get there. These are no ordinary women, these are powerful women. Hilary Clintonrsquos personality surely proves that point: her pitch for the presidency showed her to be a great deal more hawk than dove.:Project aims to help women stand for electionYet Fukuyama ndash and others ndash might nevertheless be right in hoping for a less violent futuremore women are at the top table. Nobody has done more to show Germany in a pacic and positively humanitarian light than Angela Merkel, even though she knew her policies risked her political standing in some quarters.To date, the performance of those like Mary Robinson, when she was Irish president, or Helle Thorning-Schmidt when Denmarkrsquos prime minister, or New Zealandrsquos Jacinda Ardern, not to mention Scotlands first minister, offers reason to hope. The ability to compromise, to use diplomatic means to defuse conflict, or find a way around an impasse is, while by no means solely a female quality, certainly one at which we are beginning to excel.Sweeping generalisation though it is, women are undoubtedly less physically combative and martial than men, though potentially nasty nevertheless. It can be seen as early as the school playground that our preferred weaponry is verbal attack and the ability to work stealthily, in ways of which Machiavelli would approve, to undermine the enemy.Irsquove never believed we are nicer than men ndash my experience has been quite the opposite. Yet in the West at least, attitudes in government and society are changing. Itrsquos now possible to be feminine and command respect. Gender no longer signals deficiency. Increasingly, even, it could be seen as a positive advantage.Growing numbers of women are rising through the democratic ranks on the strength of their strategic and negotiating skills, rather than their gung-ho, macho credentials. As a new generation is attracted to these roles, seeing that they no longer need to act tough in order to succeed, then things might just improve. Perhaps it is a reasonable assumption after all that, with more female hands at the tiller, nations will become stronger and safer.

title: spanish-prime-minister-called-clara-ponsati-extradition-hearing
story: Clara Ponsati faces a charge of sedition over her role in Cataloniarsquos unsanctioned independence referendum in .At a procedural hearing at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Thursday, her lawyer Gordon Jackson QC said they would call senior figures from Spainrsquos judiciary and political world to give evidence.:Former Catalan minister bailed after court appearanceHe said an issue to be considered was whether Ms Ponsati, a professor at the University of St Andrews, would face a fair trial in Spain.Mr Jackson said: ldquoWe intend to call senior figures from the judicial and political worlds in Spain, including the Prime Minister, former prime minister, former foreign minister and heads of political parties.ldquoWe are very much on the line of the ability to get a fair trial, standing what has already been happening in related cases in Spain.ldquoThere are people in jail in Spain in related cases. There is certainly going to be focus on the independence of the judiciary and the ability to get any fair trial for this womanshe goes back to Spain.Ms Ponsati could be sentenced to  years behind barsconvicted, with nine other Catalan officials given jail sentences of between nine and  years for the same offence in autumn this year.She faces a single charge of sedition, which relates to the organising of the referendum in her role as education minister, her solicitor Aamer Anwar said previously.The hearing took place before Sherf Nigel Ross, who set a date for a further procedural hearing at the court of January .A full hearing is expected to take place later next year.Speaking outside the court on Thursday, Mr Anwar said: ldquoClara regards it as surreal that she is accused of treason when the Catalan Government executed a law democratically voted on in the Catalan Parliament elected by the Catalan people.He added: ldquoA true democracy guarantees the absolute freedom of expression and politicians must be able to speak freely, independently and without fear of any form of prosecution or punishment.:Clara Ponsati lsquoready to fightrsquo against extradition to SpainldquoSpain claims that it is a modern democracy but with over half of the Catalan Government either in exile or in custody, the prosecutions are seen as a politically motivated attempt to criminalise the desire of independence of more than two million voters and endangering the very ing of the rule of law.He concluded: ldquoClara Ponsati needs your support as she takes on the might of the Spanish state but this independence movement is bigger than any one inidual, prisoner, politician or exile, what Catalonia does next will the determine the destiny of generations to come.After the hearing, Ms Ponsati and Mr Anwar went to speak to supporters waving Catalan flags and banners who had gathered opposite the court.

title: helen-mcardle-social-media-forum-people-faced-facts-dont-like-prefer-call-lies
story: Firstly, it wasnt fake. Secondly, social media is the perfect breeding ground for conspiracy theories and confirmation bias. And thirdly , the real issues are all too quickly lost in a debate that descends into acrimony, point-scoring and knee-jerk denialism.Modern day exchanges seem to be about more heat than light. There is no context, nuance or attempt to delve into the underlying causes of events.: If there are more GPs than ever, why are workloads increasing and appointments harder to get Instead, this poor young boy with pneumonia was seized on by supporters of Boris Johnson and Brexit as a fabrication designed to advance a Labour agenda.The boys mother was quoted in the Labour-supporting Daily Mirror saying that the experience had convinced her to vote for Jeremy Corbyns party - but that doesnt mean that it never happened.Notably it was a local paper, the Yorkshire Evening Post, that broke the story, and hospital bosses apologised for the situation blaming a shortage of beds - no one there was denying it.The only people who were were posting from anonymous Facebook and Twitter accounts, claiming a "friend of a friend" said it never happened.But social media is a forum where people faced with facts they dont like prefer to call them lies.The key issue missed in all this furore, however, is why were there no beds for Jack For years, the NHS in England - like Scotland - has been cutting hospital bed numbers. Since , NHS England has cut ,of its hospital and mental health beds in Scotland they are down by , over the same period - a fall of %.This is not a new trend in either nation though. From the s onwards there has been a steady reduction in NHS beds amid the rise of keyhole surgeries with shorter recovery times, day procedures and a sht towards cheaper community-based care.: NHS Highlands whistleblowers have been let down again in row over compensationBut Jacks case is not really an argument for greater investment in hospitals or AE so much as in social care, where funding is sorely lacking.The real reason there was no bed for him is probably because the hospital beds were occupied by elderly patients well enough to leave, but with no social care package or care home bed in place.In a rush to turn his case into a symbol of NHS failure, we risk cementing the same disregard for social care that has led successive governments to underfund it.But try telling that to the Twittersphere.

title: general-election-2019-parties-use-facebook-final-week-campaign

title: review-lion-king-playhouse-edinburgh-five-stars
story: The Lion KingThe Playhouse, EdinburghNeil CooperFive starsIt really is a jungle out there in this latest tour of Disneyrsquos epic staging of the companyrsquos now quarter-of-a-century old Hamlet-inspired animated feature. And Julie Taymorrsquos production puts flesh on the bones of Roger Allers and Irene Mecchirsquos book about lion cub Simbarsquos coming of age in the face of betrayal, exile and death in a quite spectacular fashion. It sets out its store from the start with the world music chorale of Circle of Le, Elton John and Tim Ricersquos opening number that incorporates Hans Zimmer and Lebo Mrsquos Nants Igonyama. This heralds the ark-load of creatures who parade through the auditorium in a rousing display of communal co-existence.This makes for the start of a vivid morality play, with Taymor and Michael Curryrsquos puppet creations navigating Garth Faganrsquos choreography across the landscapes of Richard Hudsonrsquos Max Ernst-inspired sets. These are framed by the dazzling washes emanating from the entire spectrum of Donald Holderrsquos lighting design. The first half is carried largely by Jean-Luc Guizonne as Simbarsquos father Mufasa, Richard Hurst as his scheming brother, Scar and Matthew Forbes as pukka hornbill, Zazu. Joshua Moabi and Mary-Anne Pity Tiekou more than hold their own as Young Simba and Young Nala, one of five teams of child actors playing the roles during the showrsquos almost four-month Edinburgh run.The second half sees Dashaun Young take up the mantle of grown-up Simba with a muscular verve that finds romance with Josslynn Hlentirsquos Nala. Almost  performers make up the le-size menagerie beyond, with the trio of malevolent hyenas hiding out in the elephantsrsquo graveyard as a grotesque gang of power-hungry desperadoes. Despite such biblical largesse, things never feel overloaded or bombastic, and while brush-strokes are necessarily broad at for a family audience, there are nuances within that. A sense of nobility and community pulse the law of the jungle story with a sense of internationalist pride that goes brilliantly beyond the call of the wild where.

title: 100-years-celebration-former-forestry-worker
story: A FOREST worker who was born three days after the the newly-formed Forestry Commission planted its first trees is celebrating his own centenary as well as that of his former employers.George Stewart, who turned  yesterday, was born in Glasgow in  but spent holidays in Aberfoyle, where he found a deep love for nature ldquorunning wild in the woods.Just days before he was born in a sandstone tenement in the industrial city, the Forestry Commission planted its first crop of trees at Monaughty Forest near Elgin.He said: ldquoIrsquom a real died-in-the-wool Glaswegian ... I couldnrsquot have been further away from the countryside but we did go to Aberfoyle for the holidays and that gave me my first taste of the countryside and I was bewitched by it all together.Mr Stewart served with the Royal Artillery in World War One touring North Africa and Italy before studying forestry at Edinburgh University.A proud district officer for the south Scotland conservancy ndash training in Lockerbie and then taking up a position in Langholm in the Scottish Borders ndash Mr Stewart worked for the Forestry Commission for  years before retiring in .Working for Forest Research took him south of the border to the north west of England before he ed to his homeland to take up the position of conservator for the west of Scotland.During his tenure he witnessed the development of the agency that manages publicly-owned forests and regulates both private and public bodies of woodland, now managed by two Scottish Government bodies, Forestry and Land Scotland and Scottish Forestry.His forestry career covered the great post-WWII expansion of forestry, the development of innovative forest research and technical development, the rise of the private forestry sector, the expansion of recreation and conservation objectives, and the devolution vote in Scotland in  and its potential implications for forestry governanceMr Stewart remembers well the devastation of the forests after a hurricane swept the central belt in January , felling thousands of trees, and was responsible for organising the response to the Great Storm.He said: ldquoWe had an enormous area which was blown flat. I remember with great clarity standing on a hill and seeing in front of me an entire plantation of perhaps  acres with every tree lying flat on the ground exactly one after the other., all in the same direction.ldquoIt was a terrible sight so the great problem we had was clearing all that timber up before it began to rot. It took about two years to do it.Established following the passing of the Forestry Act of , the Forestry Commission mobilised a vast new workforce.Working for the commission was an honour for Mr Stewart, who sees it as a vital source of rural employment.He said: ldquoFirst thing about the Forestry and me is I chose it to be my profession and I think it was a very wise choice for a young man to make. The Forestry has always been this wonderful countryside in which we live and thatrsquos a great privilege and itrsquos a privilege that we donrsquot appreciate enough.ldquoThe Forestry plays its part in the countryside, trees and woods, small forests, big forests - itrsquos all part of the wonderful countryside that we have but I very much believe that the countryside must be a living countryside where people live and work, not only enjoy it but find employment there.ldquoThe Forestry Commission plays a very big part in providing employment in this countryside of ours. I like to think of the countryside with all its wonderful wildle as being part of all that we have and enjoy and the privilege of living in it.Although officially retiring in , Mr Stewart served as chair of the Scottish Wildle Trust as well as on the council of the National Trust for Scotland. He has been a member of the Royal Scottish Forestry Society since  and was made an honorary vice president there earlier this year.

title: general-election-2019-55-seats-exit-poll-suggests-vindication-nicola-sturgeon
story: The First Minister put a second independence referendum at the heart of her campaign, saying a vote for her party was not just a chance to ldquoescape Brexit, but that she would interpret it as a ldquoclear instruction for holding Indyref in .Although Ms Sturgeon dialled down the independence message in the closing days, urging people to vote SNP tactically mainly to lock Mr Johnson out of power, the unambiguous text of her manesto will allow her to claim a mandate for that new vote on the constitution.:Scotland Decides: Exit poll predicts Conservative majority as polls closeThe pollrsquos prediction of a thumping Tory majority south of the border and the near certainty that Brexit will now go ahead, can only add fuel to those demands.The constitutional crisis is likely to be one of the first thingrsquos in Mr Johnsonrsquos in-tray.The generic referendum legislation which would pave the way for Indyref is due to complete its passage through Holyrood next Thursday.Ms Sturgeon has also said she will request the transfer of power to hold the referendum, under Section  of the  Scotland Act, before Christmas.The Prime Minister has said he will simply mark it ldquo to sender, but to dismiss it out of hand would be to invite a further backlash and boost support for independence.However evenMr Johnson attempts to let the SNP leader down gently, the issue is now certain to dominate the next Scottish Parliament election in .If the poll is correct, and the SNP have achieved a second tsunami in a general election, there is a very real chance that the party will do likewise at Holyrood, repeating the absolute majority of .Even Scottish Secretary Alister Jack and former Scottish Tory Ruth Davidson have said a win on that scale would constitute a ldquodemocratic mandate for another referendum.The First Minister last night urged caution in response to the poll.She said on Twitter it suggested a ldquogood night for the SNP, but added: ldquoit is just an exit poll and there are many marginals, so letrsquos just wait and see. What it indicates UK wide though is grim.The exit poll also suggested the profound failure of the Scottish Tory campaign, which was almost exclusively focused on attacking Ms Sturgeon and on Indyref.Both proved considerably more popular than what the Tories were offering - Boris and Brexit.In a country where Mr Johnsonrsquos popularity rating is abysmal and almost two-thirds of people voted to Remain in the EU, the Tories were always going to struggle.But they convinced themselves they had found a way to avoid a wipe-out of their  MPs, and talked up their chances of winning In Lanark  Hamilton East and Central Ayrshire.Ms Davidson even promised this week that she would swim naked in Loch Nessthe SNP won more than  seats.ldquoI will happily wager to strip naked on the banks of Loch Ness and subject myself to a Hogmanay wild swimming session should such a result occur, safe in the knowledge that my modestywill remain unmolested," she wrote.Both she and Nessie appear set for a shock.Scottish Labour, too, had hopes of holding on to many of their seven MPs, and possibly regaining some of their former heartland seats in Glasgow and North Lanarkshire.However the party suffered because of Jeremy Corbyn, who was not seen as a credible candidate for Prime Minister, and because the SNP offered an alternative which was equally opposed to Mr Johnson, clear in its opposition to Brexit, and stood up for Scotland.:General election : When will Scotlands results be announced In Richard Leonard, Scottish Labour also has a leader who, while he improved over the campaign, remains an inconspicuous, lacklustre figure after more than two years in the job.Having led Scottish Labour to a fth-place rout in Mayrsquos European election, his position must now be in doubt.Willie Rennie must also be consideringthis was his last election after eight years as Scottish Liberal Democrat leader and whether it is time for a new face for .His party had four MPs in , including the rock-solid seat of Orkney  Shetland.But it was the East Dunbartonshire incumbent, Jo Swinson, who really mattered, alienating voters with a manesto pledge to stop Brexit without another referendum, and patronising nonsense about her being the next Prime Minister.The LibDems also had a chance to overturn the smallest majority in the UK - the two votes of the SNPrsquos Stephen Gethins in North East Fe.If they have failed - and this is Mr Renniersquos patch at Holyrood as well - it will be humiliating.

title: election-worry-democracy
story: Being honest is less important than being visibleDid it say this on the white board in Dominic Cummingsrsquo office  It might as well have done.Politicians have never been saints, but systematic dishonesty from the very top of a party is an innovation, and a dangerous one.Boris Johnson was a proven liar before the campaign and where he led, the Tory campaign followed, with a doctored video of the shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer plastered all over social media and a brazen attempt by Conservative central office to hoodwink people on Twitter by posing as a fact-checking organisation.Like complacent old colonials faced with complaining locals, senior Tories casually batted away criticism of it all. The party even briefed journalists earlier this week that a Tory aide had been punched by a Labour activist, which was a big fat lie served up with an extra helping of tripe.The Tories may not have been the only offenders ndash the Lib Dems used misleading bar charts on campaign literature and the SNP had to withdraw a leaflet because of a  claim about Jo Swinson ndash but the Conservativesrsquo flagrancy has been of a dferent order, apparently driven by the cynical logic that getting found out is worth it to buy extra airtime during the ensuing row.We should all worry for our democracy. A rot has set in. :Conservatives win majority in general election as SNP vote surgesIt is an age of political pygmiesAll main UK party leaders had substantial negative approval ratings as polling opened and a YouGov survey on Wednesday found that two thirds of voters were unenthusiastic about the election.Who can blame them  Jeremy Corbynrsquos refusal to apologise in his Andrew Neil interview for his handling of anti-Semitism, and his feeble lie about the Queenrsquos Speech, were head-in-hands moments. But the spectacle of politicians hurling blame at each other following the death of Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones in the London terrorist attack, was the nadir of a grim campaign. The Conservatives behaved like greyhounds out of the traps as soon as the period of campaigning purdah expired with their attempts to blame Labour .Voters feel they deserve better. Theyrsquod be right.Broadcasters have to get better at handling politiciansWhen Boris Johnson, the aforementioned serial liar, started refusing to appear on television, broadcasters were put on the spot. Channel  stood up for themselves and the democratic process by replacing Mr Johnson with an ice sculpture during their debate on climate change, and then facing down the Tories when they complainedto Ofcom.The BBC however has struggled to get it right. Like ITV, they failed to get a firm commitment from Mr Johnson at the outset of the campaign to a one-to-one interview with Mr Neil. Mr Neil telling viewers the questions he would have asked Mr Johnson was effective, but not enough to reset the imbalance after other party leaders had undergone a proper interview.On Monday night ndash the day Mr Johnson took a reporterrsquos phone off him to avoid looking at the picture of a four-year-old left for hours on the floor of Leeds General Hospital ndash the Tories refused to put anyone on Newsnight, so Labour frontbencher Barry Gardiner went on alone. The Tories were then rewarded for not turning up when, in spite of Mr Johnsonrsquos dire performance that day, the interview by Emily Maitlis became an attack on Jeremy Corbyn for not visiting enough hospitals. How can it be right to let the no-shows off and turn all the heat on those who submit to scrutiny Politicians are boldly testing the boundaries of the acceptable. Broadcasters must push back harder.:General election : How every constituency has voted in ScotlandOn Monday night ndash the day Mr Johnson took a reporters phone off him to avoid looking at the picture of a four-year-old left on the floor of Leeds General Hospital ndash the Tories refused to put anyone on Newsnight, so Labour frontbencher Barry Gardiner went on alone. The Tories were then rewarded for not turning up when, in spite of Mr Johnsons dire performance that day, the interview by Emily Maitlis became an attack on Jeremy Corbyn for not visiting enough hospitals. How can it be right to let the no-shows off and turn all the heat on those who submit to scrutiny Politicians are boldly testing the boundaries of the acceptable. Broadcasters must push back harder.Boris Johnson is not a great campaignerHe was seen as the antithesis of Theresa May but one of the campaignrsquos surprises has been the uncanny similarity between Mr Johnson and the Maybot.During his encounters with the public, Mr Johnson has at times seemed just as awkward and tongue-tied and the bonhomie as forced.He seems to be regarded by his own side as even more of a liability in interviews.Many Conservative MPs regard him as a charlatan, but voted for him as leader because of his fabled campaigning skills.Itrsquos lucky for them that the Brexit Party more or less collapsed itself at the outset of the campaign to help the Tories, because itrsquos very unlikely Mr Johnson would have achieved those poll ratings otherwise.The two-party system is still robustThe Liberal Democrats were on  per cent in the polls in September and Jo Swinson dared to dream of being the next Prime Minister.But Ms Swinsonrsquos policy of revoking Article  was an unhelpful distraction and Ms Swinson herself went down poorly with voters. This decline, coupled with the usual suffocating squeeze on the Lib Dems, turned the partyrsquos dreams to dust.The SNP may have managed to break the mould in Scotland but the Lib Dems will have to regroup and rethinkthe two-party system is to be prised open.Christmas elections are a bad ideaA spoof ad of Love Actually must have seemed like a wizard ruse to the Tories.The rest of us thought ldquoOh God, no.The idea of an ingratiating Mr Johnson using one the most saccharine of British movies as a vehicle to bash us over the head with his misleading Brexit policy, induced the sort of dyspeptic feeling normally associated with downing an ill-advised gingerbread latte at speed while Christmas shopping.And it wasnrsquot good. Mr Johnson was wisely prevented from speaking during the adbut he still managed to come over as glib and insincere in writing.Jeremy Corbynrsquos Mean Tweets fireside chat, reading out offensive remarks about himself on social media, was more easygoing and less forced, though he clearly hasnrsquot been reading the same Twitter feeds as methatrsquos the worst he could come up with.Thank God the campaign ended before they sullied any more of our shared festive heritage.If Santa thinks Brexit is a good idea, we donrsquot want to know.

title: issue-day-cats-movie
story: Itrsquos an Andrew Lloyd Webber musical Cats was composed by him, inspired by the  poetry collection, Old Possums Book of Practical Cats, by T.S. Eliot, of which Lloyd Webber was a lelong fan. It tells the tale of the Jellicles, a tribe of cats on the one night of the year they come together to make the "Jellicle choice" ndash which cat is to be reborn to a new le.The musical split the critics The feline extravaganza had positive reviews when it first staged in the West End in May  ndash with Elaine Paige playing the role of Grizabella, performing the enduring song, Memory ndash but received mixed reviews in New York the following year. It ultimately became an industry juggernaut, with the London production running for  years and the Broadway show running for .It became a phenomenon When it first staged, nothing like it had entertained audiences before ndash with the whole of the theatre used as a stage, for example, and the standout track, Memory, etching itself in the national consciousness. It also drew to the theatre a new demographic previously turned off by "elitist" productions. In its first eight years in the West End, every seat in the house was sold.Now itrsquos a movie A lavish production ndash with an estimated budget of pound million ndash is set to take to the silver screen next week, based on the stage show and directed by Tom Hooper, who previously helmed s Les Miserables.It has a starry cast Dame Judi Dench, Sir Ian McKellen, James Cordon, Idris Elba and Taylor Swt to name but a few. English ballerina, Francesca Hayward, who is a principal dancer in the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden, also stars, as does Australian actress Rebel Wilson and US singer, Jenner Hudson.The trailer sparked a backlash When the first teaser trailer dropped in the summer, the internet went wild, with ided reactions to the design of the cats which, using CGI, depicted them as photo-realistic human-like characters.All publicity is good publicity It was the number one trending topic on Twitter worldwide for a spell, certainly boosting the moviersquos profile.And Hooper said the response aided the continuing production: ldquoWersquod only finished shooting in March, so all the visual effects [in the trailer] were at quite an early stagehellipWhen you watch the finished film, yoursquoll see that some of the designs of the cats have moved on since then, and certainly our understanding of how to use the technology to make them work has gone up, too."It already has an award nomination The song, Beautul Ghosts, written by Swt ndash who plays Bombalurina in the film _ and Lloyd Webber, has been nominated for Best Original Song at the Golden Globes, which take place in January.The movie opens on December .MAUREEN SUGDEN
